p: An estimated 71 million people worldwide are chronically infected with hepatitis C [ 1] and 257 million with hepatitis B [ 1â€“ 4]. Combined, hepatitis C and hepatitis B are estimated to cause 1.34 million deaths annually, and viral hepatitis is now the 7th leading cause of death globally, ahead of HIV and malaria [ 2, 3]. The burden of hepatitis B and C disease in 2013 was estimated at 38.7 million disability-adjusted life years (DALYs), an increase of at least 25% since 1990 [ 3, 4].
